Description: Lower part of furnishing textile or shawl?; the textile is in undyed linen plain weave with two square panels in tapestry and decoartion of undyed linen, red and green wool loops; one end is preserved with fringe (26cm long); two simple selvedge are preserved and the other edge is cut; 4cm above the fringe is a band of open weave (c.9cm high); c.24cm above the open weave are two square tapestry panels (31x36cm); the squares are framed by the same freize of medallions on a beige and purple background; in each angle is a star-shaped motif in yellow wool with a centre in blue and red wool, between the stars are baskets in yellow and orange full of fruits and vegetables, the central scene on each medallion shows a naked human figure - on the right square is a man wearing a blue mantle running to the right, holding an object (sheild?), his right arm is raised - on the left square is a woman? wearing a blue and red mantle, walking to the left, holding an object (unidentified), her left hand is raised - both figures are in purple on a beige background; the two panels are surrounded by loops in undyed linen and green and red wool (c.3cm long), one row every 2cm; plain weave: mwarp-undyed linen (S/20), weft-undyed linen (S/10); tapestry on paired threads: warp-undyed linen (S/7), weft-undyed linen (S/24), yellow, orange, pink, red, green, blue, purple wool (S/32); slip tapestry closed with oversewing: undyed linen (S spun Z ply); flying threads: undyed linen (S spun Z ply); loops: undyed linen (S spun Z ply twisted), red and green wool (S spun Z ply twisted?)
Bibliographic references: Budge 1922 / British Museum. Guide to the fourth, fifth and sixth Egyptian rooms, and the Coptic room (p.228) (Table case H, no. 20)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Sir Ernest A T Wallis Budge
